The following engineering and administrative controls help prevent releases of regulated substances:

- the regulated substances, in both liquid and gaseous forms, are produced, stored, used and recovered within dedicated process equipment 

- bulk quantities of flammable liquids awaiting further processing are contained in double-wall tanks installed below ground to protect them from impact or other hazards (e.g., fire); 

- there are alarms and sensors installed within equipment that prevent overfilling of process vessels and tanks by shutting down the feed system when a high level is reached 

- in many instances, process piping and vessels are built to standards that exceed U.S. code requirements 

- the process is monitored and controlled by trained Chemical Operators in a centralized control room via a computer-based distributed control system (DCS)

- equipment and piping are visually inspected by plant personnel on a regular basis

- gas sensors are installed in strategic locations throughout the facility to detect releases of regulated substances, should they occur, and

- safety instrumented systems and emergency shutdown systems are tested at least annually.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A) THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES AT THE STATIONARY SOURCE Wacker is committed to the Safety, Health and Security of our team members, contractors, visitors and customers, and to our neighboring community.  WACKER Charleston continually strives to meet or exceed all applicable Environmental, Health, Safety and Security laws, regulations and other requirements in all of its operations at all of its facilities.



At the WACKER Charleston, TN site, we seek to prevent accidental releases of hazardous substances through a combination of robustly engineered equipment, use of proven, highly reliable chemical processes and advanced technology that minimizes reliance on human responses.  WACKER's approach also involves extensive training of our chemical operations team members in the many detailed operating procedures that have been developed.  We inspect our facility thoroughly on a frequent and regular basis to ensure that any issues that are found are addressed before they become significant concerns.



WACKER's commitment to protecting people and the environment extends to its approach to emergency preparedness and response.  To ensure that the effects of any releases that do occur are minimized, Wacker has established a full-time, fully trained professional fire department and emergency response team equipped with "state-of-the-art" response equipment.





B)  THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The Wacker Charleston Site is a chemical manufacturing facility that produces hyper-pure crystalline polysilicon for the solar energy and semi-conductor industries.  The site operates on a continuous basis, seven days per week.  The highly integrated and interconnected process is divided into production units with specific functions that operate independently.  



WACKER uses several regulated substances above threshold quantities to manufacture polysilicon.  



In compliance with RMP requirements, Wacker has conducted

an Off-site Consequence Analysis and determined that, under some circumstances, a release of a regulated substance could result in off-site consequences.



C) THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

WACKER's general accidental release prevention program was developed to comply with the following regulations and requirements:



? EPA 40 CFR 68 - Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (Risk Management Plans)

? OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 - Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals 

? OSHA 29 CFR 1910.120(q) - Hazardous Waste Operations & Emergency Response (Emergency response program to hazardous substance releases)

? Other EPA, OSHA, DOT and State regulations

? Recognized and generally accepted engineering practices, codes and standards, and

? WACKER Environmental, Health, Safety and Security standard procedures



The chemical accident prevention / process safety management program includes the following elements:

- Employee Participation

- Process Safety Information

- Process Hazard Analysis

- Operating Procedures

- Process Operations & Maintenance Procedures Training

- Contractor Safety

- Pre-Startup Safety Reviews

- Mechanical Integrity

- Safe Work Permit system that includes Hot Work, Lockout/Tagout, Opening of Pipelines and Confined Space Entry

- Management of Change

- Incident Investigation

- Emergency Preparedness and Response

- Compliance Audits



The following engineering and administrative controls help prevent releases of regulated substances:

- the regulated substances, in both liquid and gaseous forms, are produced, stored, used and recovered within dedicated process equipment 

- bulk quantities of flammable liquids awaiting further processing are contained in double-wall tanks installed below ground to protect them from impact or other hazards (e.g., fire); 

- there are alarms and sensors installed within equipment that prevent overfilling of process vessels and tanks by

shutting down the feed system when a high level is reached 

- in many instances, process piping and vessels are built to standards that exceed U.S. code requirements 

- the process is monitored and controlled by trained Chemical Operators in a centralized control room via a computer-based distributed control system (DCS)

- equipment and piping are visually inspected by plant personnel on a regular basis

- gas sensors are installed in strategic locations throughout the facility to detect releases of regulated substances, should they occur, and

- safety instrumented systems and emergency shutdown systems are tested at least annually.



D) THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The site incurred an incident meeting the RMP reporting requirements on September 7, 2017 due to an unforeseen catastrophic failure of a piece of mechanical equipment.

 



E)  THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

WACKER staffs a full-time Fire Department using highly trained Fire Fighters to respond to all emergencies that may occur at the WACKER site.  The Fire Department employs site Emergency Action Plans when responding to any type of site emergency.  The Emergency Action Plans take into account different types of emergencies that could foreseeably occur.  



In the event of an emergency requiring assistance from outside agencies, WACKER personnel will make all required notifications.  The Wacker Fire Department staff, working in conjunction with the applicable local, state and federal agency representatives, will jointly decide on how to ensure neighboring communities and property are protected.



In the event of a release of one or more of the regulated substances or other hazardous material, our facility Fire Department would use chemical-specific and unit-specific response plans and procedures to address the emergency at the earliest stage possible so as to prevent escalation of the incident.  In plant locations where there is recognized fire potential, automatic fire protection systems ha

ve been installed including sprinklers, deluge systems, foam systems for fire and/or vapor suppression, or clean agent systems.



We regularly participate in the activities of the Bradley County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  We work with the Bradley County Fire and Rescue Department to conduct facility tours for personnel who may one day have to respond, to support required facility inspections and to provide opportunities for joint training exercises.



Professional technicians test our fire protection system on a monthly basis, including signals, alarms and sprinkler protection of specified processing areas.  Similarly, service technicians perform monthly inspections and service on our respiratory protection equipment, and annual inspections on all fire extinguishers.



Facility personnel test our fire pumps, safety showers and eyewash stations on a weekly basis.  Facility personnel also conduct regular testing of the uninterruptable power supply and emergency power generators, which will allow the facility to operate in a limited capacity to maintain process safety in the event of a major electrical power interruption from our supplier.



Site personnel who are members of the Fire Department participate in frequent training and drills.  They also receive training on emergency response procedures and the proper use of protective and response equipment.   The Fire Department will maintain both the chemical protective clothing and response equipment.



F) PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Wacker Charleston continually seeks to improve its processes through advancements in technology and automation.  The newly constructed hyper-pure polysilicon facility is state of the art and represents the culmination of 50 years of polysilicon manufacturing experience.  With every project, Wacker still seeks further to improve quality and enhance safety and environmental protection.  Following the release incident in September 2017 which led to the temporary sh

utdown of the plant, Wacker, along with independent consultants, investigated the incidents, reviewed the site's safety program, and developed recommendations for improvements to site and process safety.  The company implemented the recommendations during the restart process.
